content:
C3-62-0742
March 10, 1962
Mr. R. L. Hirshberg Program Officer AID Mission to China Taipei
Subject: Project-type & Non-project-type Excess Property
Dear Mr. Hirshberg:
Pursuant to your letter MC-2747 dated February 20, 1962 in which you expressed concern over the storage conditions and disposal of the subject excess properties and urged undertaking of remedial measures. We wish to furnish you the following explanations:
I. Requests for machine tools from some Arsenals and other MND production facilities were acknowledged by CUSA with condi- tions that requirement and end-use justifications be furnished and budget of funding assured within a week. Since three weeks have elapsed, we have written MND declining their re- quest for reservations.
II. On the storage of Project-type excess equipment, immediate contact has been made with BES for improvement. They explained that since they have no godowns for storage purpose, all arrived equipment were placed in open yard. However, enough tarpaulins are being used for covering up. Frequent inspections of the equipment by interested parties are the principal reason for the unsatisfactory storage conditions to which more attention will be paid from now on, they added.
III. Under Project No. 99-471, all excess equipment delivered upon requests have been duly allocated and utilized. However, you will recall that during a period about one year ago, sizable quantities of excess equipment which had not been requested were shipped from USA and effort had constantly been made to utilize these unexpected arrivals to the best advantage. Major portion has thus been allocated or sold though there is

Mr. R. L. Hirshberg
Program Officer
AID Mission to China
Taipei
Subject: Project-type & Non-project-type
Excess Property
Dear Mr. Hirshberg:
Pursuant to your letter MC-2747 dated February 20, 1962 in
which you expressed concern over the storage conditions and
disposal of the subject excess properties and urged undertaking
of remedial measures. We wish to furnish you the following
explanations:
I. Requests for machine tools from some Arsenals and other
MND production facilities were acknowledged by CUSA with condi-
tions that requirement and end-use justifications be furnished
and budget of funding assured within a week. Since three
weeks have elapsed, we have written MND declining their re-
quest for reservations.
II. On the storage of Project-type excess equipment, immediate
contact has been made with BES for improvement. They explained
that since they have no godowns for storage purpose, all arrived
equipment were placed in open yard. However, enough tarpaulins
are being used for covering up. Frequent inspections of the
equipment by interested parties are the principal reason for
the unsatisfactory storage conditions to which more attention
will be paid from now on, they added.
III. Under Project No. 99-471, all excess equipment delivered
upon requests have been duly allocated and utilized. However,
you will recall that during a period about one year ago, sizable
quantities of excess equipment which had not been requested
were shipped from USA and effort had constantly been made to
utilize these unexpected arrivals to the best advantage.

paragraphs.content: Mr. R. L. Hirshberg Program Officer AID Mission to China Taipei

Pursuant to your letter MC-2747 dated February 20, 1962 in which you expressed concern over the storage conditions and disposal of the subject excess properties and urged undertaking of remedial measures. We wish to furnish you the following explanations:

I. Requests for machine tools from some Arsenals and other MND production facilities were acknowledged by CUSA with condi- tions that requirement and end-use justifications be furnished and budget of funding assured within a week. Since three weeks have elapsed, we have written MND declining their re- quest for reservations.

II. On the storage of Project-type excess equipment, immediate contact has been made with BES for improvement. They explained that since they have no godowns for storage purpose, all arrived equipment were placed in open yard. However, enough tarpaulins are being used for covering up. Frequent inspections of the equipment by interested parties are the principal reason for the unsatisfactory storage conditions to which more attention will be paid from now on, they added.

III. Under Project No. 99-471, all excess equipment delivered upon requests have been duly allocated and utilized. However, you will recall that during a period about one year ago, sizable quantities of excess equipment which had not been requested were shipped from USA and effort had constantly been made to utilize these unexpected arrivals to the best advantage.
